awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Advancing Success in STEM Undergraduate Research and Education (ASSURE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The award to Alabama A&M University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines. The overarching goal of the project is to employ evidence-based strategies and activities for retaining, training, teaching, and graduating undergraduate STEM students. The project will impact more than two thousand undergraduate STEM majors at the University. Currently, 91% of students at Alabama A&M University are African American.

The project has three specific goals that tie into the overarching goal: 1)  to augment a robust undergraduate program by retaining, mentoring and graduating underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines; 2)  to enhance the quality of students' learning experience and depth of knowledge by expanding undergraduate research opportunities; and 3) to enhance STEM faculty members' expertise in effective evidence-based pedagogical methodologies. Carefully designed activities and strategies are employed to achieve the following outcomes: a 10% reduction of attrition in lower level undergraduate gate-keeping courses; a 20% increase in the number of students matriculating in STEM fields; a 25% increase in students' participation in interactive discovery-based undergraduate research; and a 20% increase in the passing rate of the Fundamentals of Engineering exam.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of ASSURE is to continue strengthening the quality of undergraduate STEM education and research at AAMU, while creating better methods for retaining, training, teaching, and graduating undergraduate STEM students.

1. Supplemental Instruction (SI):

SI was successful in improving the number of passing grades (A, B or C) in STEM gatekeeper courses where SI Leaders offered tutoring sessions. In classes with SI Leaders:
SI had 1108 participants. 71.3% of participants passed, while 58.4% of non-participants passed.

2. The Calculus Enrichment Program (CEP):

Over the six years we offered CEP, 140 students were accepted and joined the program. During the program we have covered almost all topics that were included in the syllabus of MTH 125 and MTH 126, especially where students showed weakness and difficulty. We first discussed the concept of the underlying topics and then solved multiple problems, for some cases in multiple ways from each area. Sometimes we had to go back to the prerequisite areas like Algebra and Trigonometry and showed their connections and applications to calculus.

3. Student Research Experience (SRE):

We had 144 undergraduate students involved in SRE. After a slow start in the first three years we found an effective way to reach out to prospective participants. 2014-2015 had 8, 2015-2016 had 12, 2016-2017 had 13, 2017-2018 had 25, 2018-2019 had 34, 2019-2020 had 35 students, 2020-2021 had 17 (without any active recruiting).

Amongst the numerous SRE students attending the annual Emerging Researchers National Conference (ERN), six SRE students were awarded first and second prizes at.

One of our SRE students, Yannick Boni, presented a poster at the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students in Seattle, Washington in November 2015. Several other students presented at other professional conferences in Alabama.

ASSURE supported AAMU's annual STEM Day activity, as all students participating in SRE were required to present a poster.

4. Fundamentals of Engineering (FE):

Dr. Nesar U. Ahmed conducted the sessions from Fall 2014 to Spring 2019. In the academic years 2016-2017 and 2017-2018 with help from Dr. Mahbub Hasan. The AAMU Civil Engineering department introduced the CE440 FE Review course in Spring 2019. Through this course FE was institutionalized, and the ASSURE FE sessions were discontinued. Topics covered: Statics, Fluid Mechanics, Hydrology, Surveying, Manning Equation and Hydraulics.

A total of 39 students signed up, with 15 students attending the review sessions on a regular basis.

5. Professional Enhancement Workshops (PEW):

Training and professional development was conducted with AAMU’s Centers of Excellence in Teaching and Learning (CETL).

6. STEM hybrid and online courses (HOC):


The university has approved the addition of a General Education level Astronomy course (and accompanying laboratory course). This course was initially designed as a in person and hybrid course, but will also to be later offered as an online course. The course was taught as a synchronous/hybrid course in Fall 2020, and as a synchronous course in Spring 2021. The enrollment numbers for Fall 2021 (full capacity) are such that we will offer a second, online section in the near future. Due to the move to teach online, Dr. Schamschula taught the introductory Physics with Calculus II (Electricity and Magnetism) course as a synchronous/hybrid course in the 2020-2021 academic year. In the summer of 2021 he converted this course to a fully asynchronous delivery mode.


Last Modified: 10/07/2021
Modified by: Marius Schamschula
